bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Rupert Blue, January 20, 1917

div1.p: Carter reports that malarial conditions in South Carolina have worsened.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Rupert Blue, January 20, 1917
div1.opener:
Relative to report of
Asst. Surgeon General,
H. R. Carter
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Baltimore, Maryland.
January 20, 1917.
The Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
f3
Sir:-
div1.p:
I have the honor to submit the following report of
my recent visit to S. C. made under Bureau orders of Jan.
& 12, 1917,.

The State Health Officer Sstates that there is complaint
of a large amount of Malaria in Bloxton Township-Colleton Co.
S.C., He states that of 67 deaths from Malaria in this county
23 of them were in this township. I submit herewith a rough map
of this township. It lays between the two Salkahatchie Swamps
the Big and the Little and is crossed by Villow swamp & by
several “branches” which are small swamps.

It is claimed that the Malaria complained of is caused
by the cutting of the lumber -of these two swamps by two lumber
Companies. The State Health Officer has planned to have an in-
vestigation of the whole subject made by a commission to consist
of a representative of the State Board: A Civilian Physician:
and A Man from the U. S. Public Health Service. A bill to that
effect has either been introduced into or passed by the S. C.
Legislature.

This investigation is planned to begin about March 1, 1917, as
the appropriation to pay the Civilian Physician will become
available on that date.

It being of course impossible for me to make an investiga-
tion of the conditions producing Malaria at this season of the
year, or even of the amount of Malaria existing with the time at
my disposal, it seemed better that I should simply visit this
section and see the general condition so as to assist the Health
Officer in planning the proper way of making a Satisfactory in-
vestigation, when he was ready and, if it meets with the views
of the Department, assisting him in it. Time and expense would
thus be saved.

I went therefore to Varnville S.C. -see Map,- and conferred
with Mr. W. C. Rentz who lives there thence was taken by Dr.
Campbell of Varnville across the Big Salkahatchie Swamp-to
confer with H. H. Rentz, in Bloxton just above Toad Bluff Crossing
After talking with him I went at his instance to see a Mr. Freeman
and Mr. J. W. Murdock, lower down the swamp on the Bloxton side
Went into the swamp, Big Salkahatchie, at an abondoned skidway
to within 1000 feet of the other side then down the swamp for 2 1/2
miles-and then out on the Bloxton side again, on the skidway now
being used. I was accompanied by three Mr. Murdock's. All of the
part of the swamp which I saw had been cut over, I was in the
swamp all of one afternoon.

After spending the night with Mr. Murdock I went to Island-
town to see Mr. Varn. He was absent and I talked with several
people there getting their views, and then saw Dr. R. A. Hudson of
Islandtown who has most of the practice in the lower end of Bloxton
where.
Thence to Waterboro and thence to Colleton Where I met Dr Carter. the physician of the Colletone Cypress Co. which is
-----3------
cutting the Little Salkahatchie and some in his own neighbor-
hood-Smoke-about 7 miles distant from the swamp. I accompanied him
to Smoke where I saw Dr. Thompson and talked with some other
people there as I did at Waterboro and Colleton.

Very obviously this inquiringyng of four days does not pretend to
be a sufficient investigation but, it is such a survey of the gener-
al problem as will throw some light on how a inquiry should be
conducted and I gave the State Health Officer such data as I
had secured and conferred with him as to how to conduct an inves-
tigation.

There is no question but that this section -Bloxton Township-
suffered severely from Malaria in 1916, much more than formerly
both in number of cases and severity of the disease. Whether this
is due in whole or in part to the cutting in the two swamps may
be a question. The cutting in the Big Salkahatchie began July or
August 1914. That of the Little Salkahatchie- has been going on
for eleven years. The people with whom I talked and -- farmers all --
believe in good faith that the clearing of the swamps is the cause
of the increase of Malaria- a number of them have moved away on
this account and others contemplate moving. Their accounts of the
coincidence of cutting timber and the increase of Malaria, if true,
is evidence of a causal relation between the two. The statements
of the three physicians I saw does not seem to bear out the above
account and implies no relation between the two. It is a matter
to be determined by investigation.

I think it is true however from what I heard outside of
Bloxton Township that there was a marked increase of Malaria
everywhere in the general section of S. C., to which a certain
portion of the increase in Bloxton Township is due.

I will add that I found that the water channels in the Big
Salkahatchie Swamp were being obstructed by the method of con-
structing the skidway tracks and, to a less extent, by the branches
of the falling trees. I advised Dr. Hayne of this and suggested
that he bring it to the attention of the Company. I do not
know that the amount of obstruction thus caused will measureably
influence Anophelus production, but it seems better, in view of t
the complaint of the cutting, not to obstruct them.

The only recommendation I have to make is that if it be
practitable a representative or representations of this Service be detailed to
assist in the investigation of this section-when it is made about
March 1, 1917, and that subsequent action of the Service be de-
termined by the result of that investigation.
